Testament: Old
Author: Moses
Synopsis: Answers two big questions: 'How did God’s relationship with the world begin?' and 'Where did the nation of Israel come from?', Many stories: Adam and Eve, Cain and Abel, Noah and the Ark, the Tower of Babel, Abraham and Isaac, Jacob's ladder, Joseph's coat of many colors.

Testament: Old
Author: Moses
Synopsis: God saves Israel from slavery in Egypt, and then enters into a special relationship with them.

Testament: Old
Author: Moses
Synopsis: God gives Israel instructions for how to worship Him.

Testament: Old
Author: Moses
Synopsis: Israel fails to trust and obey God, and wanders in the wilderness for 40 years.

Testament: Old
Author: Moses
Synopsis: Moses gives Israel instructions (in some ways, a recap of the laws in Exodus–Numbers) for how to love and obey God in the Promised Land.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: Israel’s titular new leader leads Israel to conquer the Promised land, then parcels out territories to the twelve tribes of Israel.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: Israel enters a cycle of turning from God, falling captive to oppressive nations, calling out to God, and being rescued by leaders God sends their way.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: Two widows lose everything, and find hope in Israel — which leads to the birth of the future King David.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: Israel demands a king, who turns out to be quite a disappointment.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: David, a man after God’s own heart, becomes king of Israel.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: The kingdom of Israel has a time of peace and prosperity under King Solomon, but afterward splits, and the two lines of kings turn away from God.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: Both kingdoms ignore God and his prophets, until they both fall captive to other world empires.

Testament: Old
Author: Ezra
Synopsis: This is a brief history of Israel from Adam to David, culminating with David commissioning the temple of God in Jerusalem.

Testament: Old
Author: Ezra
Synopsis: David’s son Solomon builds the temple, but after centuries of rejecting God, the Babylonians take the southern Israelites captive and destroy the temple.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: The Israelites rebuild the temple in Jerusalem, and a scribe named <Answer> teaches the people to once again obey God’s laws.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: The city of Jerusalem is in bad shape, so <Answer> rebuilds the wall around the city.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: Someone hatches a genocidal plot to bring about Israel’s extinction, and <Answer> must face the emperor to ask for help.

Testament: Old
Author: None
Synopsis: Satan attacks a righteous man named <Answer>, and <Answer> and his friends argue about why terrible things are happening to him.

Testament: Old
Author: Many
Synopsis: A collection of 150 songs that Israel sang to God (and to each other) — kind of like a hymnal for the ancient Israelites.

Testament: Old
Author: Solomon and Other Wise Men
Synopsis: A collection of sayings written to help people make wise decisions that bring about justice.

Testament: Old
Author: Solomon
Synopsis: A philosophical exploration of the meaning of life—with a surprisingly nihilistic tone for the Bible.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: A love song (or collection of love songs) celebrating love, desire, and marriage.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: God sends the prophet Isaiah to warn <Answer> of future judgment—but also to tell them about a coming king and servant who will 'bear the sins of many.'

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: God sends a prophet to warn Israel about the coming Babylonian captivity, but the people don’t take the news very well.

Testament: Old
Author: Jeremiah
Synopsis: A collection of dirges lamenting the fall of Jerusalem after the Babylonian attacks.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: God chooses a man to speak for Him (the author) to Israel, to tell them the error of their ways and teach them justice.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> becomes a high-ranking wise man in the Babylonian and Persian empires, and has prophetic visions concerning Israel’s future.

Testament: Old
Author: N<Answer>one
Synopsis: <Answer> is told to marry a prostitute who leaves him, and he must bring her back: a picture of God’s relationship with Israel.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: God sends a plague of locusts to Judge Israel, but his judgment on the surrounding nations is coming, too.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: A shepherd named <Answer> preaches against the injustice of the Northern Kingdom of Israel.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> warns the neighboring nation of Edom that they will be judged for plundering Jerusalem.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: A disobedient prophet runs from God, is swallowed by a great fish, and then preaches God’s message to the city of Nineveh.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> confronts the leaders of Israel and Judah regarding their injustice, and prophecies that one day the Lord himself will rule in perfect justice.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> foretells of God’s judgment on Nineveh, the capital of Assyria.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> pleads with God to stop the injustice and violence in Judah, but is surprised to find that God will use the even more violent Babylonians to do so.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: God warns that he will judge Israel and the surrounding nations, but also that he will restore them in peace and justice.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: The people have abandoned the work of restoring God’s temple in Jerusalem, and so <Answer> takes them to task.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: The prophet <Answer> calls Israel to return to God, and records prophetic visions that show what’s happening behind the scenes.

Testament: Old
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: God has been faithful to Israel, but they continue to live disconnected from Him — so God sends <Answer> to call them out.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: This is an account of Jesus’ life, death, and resurrection, focusing on Jesus’ role as the true king of the Jews.

Testament: New
Author: John <Answer>
Synopsis: This brief account of Jesus’ earthly ministry highlights Jesus’ authority and servanthood.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> writes the most thorough account of Jesus’ life, pulling together eyewitness testimonies to tell the full story of Jesus.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> lists stories of signs and miracles with the hope that readers will believe in Jesus.

Testament: New
Author: Luke
Synopsis: Jesus returns to the Father, the Holy Spirit comes to the church, and the gospel of Jesus spreads throughout the world.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul summarizes how the gospel of Jesus works in a letter to the churches at Rome, where he plans to visit.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul writes a disciplinary letter to a fractured church in Corinth, and answers some questions that they’ve had about how Christians should behave.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul writes a letter of reconciliation to the church at Corinth, and clears up some concerns that they have.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul hears that the <Answer> churches have been lead to think that salvation comes from the law of Moses, and writes a (rather heated) letter telling them where the false teachers have it wrong.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul writes to the church at Ephesus about how to walk in grace, peace, and love.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: An encouraging letter to the church of Philippi from Paul, telling them how to have joy in Christ.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul writes the church at Colossae a letter about who they are in Christ, and how to walk in Christ.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul has heard a good report on the church at Thessalonica, and encourages them to 'excel still more' in faith, hope, and love.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul instructs the <Answer> on how to stand firm until the coming of Jesus.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul gives his protegé <Answer> instruction on how to lead a church with sound teaching and a godly example.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul is nearing the end of his life, and encourages <Answer> to continue preaching the word.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul advises <Answer> on how to lead orderly, counter-cultural churches on the island of Crete.

Testament: New
Author: Paul
Synopsis: Paul strongly recommends that <Answer> accept his runaway slave as a brother, not a slave.

Testament: New
Author: None
Synopsis: A letter encouraging Christians to cling to Christ despite persecution, because he is greater.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer> - Likely Brother of Jesus
Synopsis: A letter telling Christians to live in ways that demonstrate their faith in action.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> writes to Christians who are being persecuted, encouraging them to testify to the truth and live accordingly.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> writes a letter reminding Christians about the truth of Jesus, and warning them that false teachers will come.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: <Answer> writes a letter to Christians about keeping Jesus’ commands, loving one another, and important things they should know.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: A very brief letter about walking in truth, love, and obedience.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: An even shorter letter about Christian fellowship.

Testament: New
Author: <Answer>
Synopsis: A letter encouraging Christians to contend for the faith, even though ungodly persons have crept in unnoticed.

Testament: New
Author: John
Synopsis: John sees visions of things that have been, things that are, and things that are yet to come.
